segment.source: Take ownership of files or other objects (Windows 10)
segment.target: Take ownership of files or other objects (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Take ownership of files or other objects security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Take ownership of files or other objects security policy setting.

segment.source: Take ownership of files or other objects
segment.target: Take ownership of files or other objects

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Take ownership of files or other objects security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Take ownership of files or other objects security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users can take ownership of any securable object in the device, including Active Directory objects, NTFS files and folders, printers, registry keys, services, processes, and threads.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users can take ownership of any securable object in the device, including Active Directory objects, NTFS files and folders, printers, registry keys, services, processes, and threads.

segment.source: Every object has an owner, whether the object resides in an NTFS volume or Active Directory database.
segment.target: Every object has an owner, whether the object resides in an NTFS volume or Active Directory database.

segment.source: The owner controls how permissions are set on the object and to whom permissions are granted.
segment.target: The owner controls how permissions are set on the object and to whom permissions are granted.

segment.source: By default, the owner is the person who or the process which created the object.
segment.target: By default, the owner is the person who or the process which created the object.

segment.source: Owners can always change permissions to objects, even when they are denied all access to the object.
segment.target: Owners can always change permissions to objects, even when they are denied all access to the object.

segment.source: Assigning this user right can be a security risk.
segment.target: Assigning this user right can be a security risk.

segment.source: Because owners of objects have full control of them, only assign this user right to trusted users.
segment.target: Because owners of objects have full control of them, only assign this user right to trusted users.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default this setting is Administrators on domain controllers and on stand-alone servers.
segment.target: By default this setting is Administrators on domain controllers and on stand-alone servers.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: By default, the Administrators group is given the Take ownership of files or other objects user right.
segment.target: By default, the Administrators group is given the Take ownership of files or other objects user right.

segment.source: Anyone or any group who has the Take ownership user right on the object.
segment.target: Anyone or any group who has the Take ownership user right on the object.

segment.source: A user who has the Restore files and directories user right.
segment.target: A user who has the Restore files and directories user right.

segment.source: Ownership can be transferred in the following ways:
segment.target: Ownership can be transferred in the following ways:

segment.source: The current owner can grant the Take ownership user right to another user if that user is a member of a group defined in the current owner's access token.
segment.target: The current owner can grant the Take ownership user right to another user if that user is a member of a group defined in the current owner's access token.

segment.source: The user must take ownership to complete the transfer.
segment.target: The user must take ownership to complete the transfer.

segment.source: A user who has the Restore files and directories user right can double-click Other users and groups and choose any user or group to assign ownership to.
segment.target: A user who has the Restore files and directories user right can double-click Other users and groups and choose any user or group to assign ownership to.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Any users with the Take ownership of files or other objects user right can take control of any object, regardless of the permissions on that object, and then make any changes that they want to make to that object.
segment.target: Any users with the Take ownership of files or other objects user right can take control of any object, regardless of the permissions on that object, and then make any changes that they want to make to that object.

segment.source: Such changes could result in exposure of data, corruption of data, or a denial-of-service condition.
segment.target: Such changes could result in exposure of data, corruption of data, or a denial-of-service condition.

segment.source: Ensure that only the local Administrators group has the Take ownership of files or other objects user right.
segment.target: Ensure that only the local Administrators group has the Take ownership of files or other objects user right.

segment.source: Restricting the Take ownership of files or other objects user right to the local Administrators group is the default configuration.
segment.target: Restricting the Take ownership of files or other objects user right to the local Administrators group is the default configuration.
